Message.Msg: Does AMZN take product inventory at least twice a year? Since they are heavily into consumer electronics - that stuff depreciates fast if it doesn't get sold. In addition I understand AMZN makes loans to their third party sellers - that's almost like floor planning that inventory as well...

Message.Title: A brief review of Amazon most recent history
Message.Msg: Amazon has a bond offering of $3 billion to raise cash. Bezos sells $197 Million dollars worth of stock to the only people that could buy and distrubute those shares (Morgan, Goldman, Deutch, etc) An upgay parade begins as institutions seek to lighten their load of shares. Bond buyers begin shorting-the-box to hedge their bond principal and gain leverage if the stock drops. The word "Trillion" is tossed about around the Amazon sewing circle. An activity seen as Apple was approaching the $700 level. Bezos declares, in a manner that probably violates Reg-FD, that Amazon is not about making profits (Yes this really happened, and yes, it was an earnings warning!).

Topic.Title: A brief review of Amazon most recent history

Message.Msg: Bruce, You make valid points and I comment you for being long, obviously you have done very well this year. But at this point do you really see (as a new investor) going long apposed to short? I know everyone is saying "it's not about earnings" ok.... that is because of all the cap ex issues. But say 5 years out will it matter? I think yes. If all goes to plan and AMZN executes flawlessly earnings are pegged at 11.14 for 2017. If that happens at today's stock price it's pe is 24. Still over priced compared to WMT ( 14) and EBAY (18). I just don't see the risk/reward being in the long's POV in the long term. - PJ

Message.Title: Not even Jeff Bezos would buy Amazon's cash flow
Message.Msg: You have to read this article. Look on Yahoo.

Topic.Title: Not even Jeff Bezos would buy Amazon's cash flow

Message.Msg: It's an eye opening article. I am amazed how well this stock is holding up given all of it's headwinds: 1) poor quality cash flow (see article) 2) deteriorating fundamentals --- decelerating sales growth, declining operating margins, declining net margins, etc. 3) loss of competitive advantage due to sales tax 4) disappointing holiday sales figures 5) strong competition --- they compete with google, sap, orcl, etc in the cloud space, they compete with appl and samsung on tablets, they compete with wmt, target, etc in retail It is possible that they miss sales and eps expectations on the next call. That would be 3 misses in a row. How does anyone buy into these levels?

Message.Title: AMZN vs Rest of Techs
Message.Msg: Let's assume AMZN has decent margins. Let's assume they will continue to grow 15% per year. Let's assume their current slow down in rate of growth goes away. Let's assume their earnings will move up quickly so their PE actually improves 20 fold to 150. Let's also assume their unique and all-conquering business model demands a premium adjustment of 100% for their PE. Or, a PE of 75. So let's assume their getting close fundamentally to AAPLs and GOOGs of the world - then, comparing valuations, then for the valuations to be somewhat on par, AAPL shares should trade for around $3,500!!!!!!!! or GOOG shares should be around $2,400!!!! Sounds absurd, no? If you answer yes, then the alternative is for AMZN to drop to a range of $45 to $82. Go figure...

Topic.Title: Amazon is charging 13 percent sales tax, for California orders

Message.Msg: Charging "sales tax" on the shipping and handling TOO! In other words adding the shipping and handling charges to the item price, THEN applying the sales tax so the shipping is being taxed. Even gift wrapping would be subject to tax. They know not what they are doing. The shipping charge is not subject to sales tax. At least it is not supposed tho be. __________________________________________ Amazon Comments: I understand your concern regarding the tax, I'd be glad to assist you. The amount of sales tax charged on your order depends upon many factors, including the identity of the seller, the type of item purchased, and the destination of the shipment. The sales tax rate applied to your order will generally be the combined state and local rate for the address to which your order is shipped. The sales tax rate applied to your order may be different for an order shipped to your home address versus an order for the very same items shipped to your work address. In accordance with state and local tax laws, the total selling price of an item will generally include item level shipping and handling charges, item level discounts, and gift wrap charges.
